ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: While the topics for each class were very interesting, and the Professor is excellent - I felt like there is more room for integrating the classes. I did not see the flow much - apart from micro to macro development/economics/policy.

I could have done without many of the readings which I did not find very interesting. It's a bit annoying to have to do weekly commentaries, particularly when you don't care for certain readings.The class tries to cover a lot of material, which combined with lots of powerpoint charts and diagrams, dilutes the learning value.

Readings were good but could have tied together better. Course needed a central theme which seemed to be missing.Lectures straight from the slides which paralleled the readings - not very helpful, could stay up to date just by reading the powerpoint.

Question 1: the readings for some weeks were better than others. I found the readings for woodfuel lecture unhelpful, but readings got better as the course progressed.Question 3: I enjoyed writing the commentaries because it helps me conceptualize all the readings together, and I also really appreciate that we got one free week. I think that more help could have been given for the midterm modelling project--maybe broken up into small groups of ~10 people outside of class where we could get a more one-on-one experience using the program and asking the professor for help/clarification. The one half-lecture we spent on it barely helped prepare us, because we weren't doing the clicking and exploring ourselves, and it's a kind of complicated program for those who have never used it before.Question 5: I really appreciate how the professor would take time to answer students' questions, and if he didn't know the answer, would make note of it, look it up later, and tell us next lecture or via email. I felt like he fostered a good atmosphere for asking questions and encouraging discussion.

The subject matter of the course was interesting and useful. I also thought that the organization of the semester was intuitive and helpful. The biggest problem with this course was the level at which it was taught. The subjects were so interesting, but the instruction and discussion was at an undergraduate level - for people with no background in energy or development. I was so excited by the readings and subjects covered in this class but constantly disappointed by the actual class sessions.
More courses like this please! This course was an excellent basic intro, I would love to be able to continue on with more advanced readings in this area.
question 6, the class runs slow but you do learn a lot.
This is an important course for everyone interested in energy.
The Homer exercise, and the research paper which allows us to research an issue of our own interest/choosing.
The instructor provided a very good basis for discussion in the class, covering a broad range of subjects relating to energy issues, with something for everyone.
discussions, term paper
HOMER assignment, and Professor Bailis.
Readings provided by the Professor
Focusing on the development/social aspects of energy.

The HOMER assignment provided the opportunity to learn a practical application of classroom readings and discussion. I also very much enjoyed the emphasis on creative discussions - they were always very interesting!
Modeling project as midterm assignment. very useful and interesting.
That it covered not only issues related to energy but also issues related to poverty and development.
The readings were always very thoughtful and often multi-disciplinary. The Homer assignment was also an excellent applied project.
Homer

I like that energy and development are tied in this course. I think it's an exciting mix, but there are so many things that need improvement with the course that I actually did not find it exciting in the end. I like how responsive the professor was to questions, and I like that the course seemed new, fresh, and up to date on many of the current issues in energy and development.
The instructor

The HOMER exercise - taught us how to use a model to actually value different types of renewable and conventional energy generation sources according to cost, emissions, resource availability metrics etc. We don't get enough hands-on modeling experience at FES - certainly not in energy - so this was a huge help. Loved it. Otherwise, I appreciated how much detail Prof. Bailis put into the lectures. His knowledge of each of the disciplines that come together to inform this material is impressive - technical, social, economic, policy etc. Also enjoyed the discussion sections at the end of each class. Most students did a great job and facilitated some interesting conversations. Was great to break up the lecture format.
a social aproach to energy issues
readings were relevant and carefully chosen. Discussions at the end of class weren't that interesting.
having a global overview about energy.
A broad range of topics.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Some of the topics towards the end sort of dragged, but I think mostly because they weren't particularly interesting to me, not because of the quality of presentation or material.

Lecture style. Too many slides, too much scattered material.Also many of the reading choices can be improved, particularly those at the beginning of the semester around the concepts of gender, access, rights, poverty, etc. The first few weeks seemed like a class on the theory of development, not a class on energy.Give students a bit more slack on the commentaries, requiring only say 8-10 out of 13 weeks.
Bowers not at all conducive to discussion.
Perhaps because the lecture material was not tested on, students' attention and participation seemed to waver by the end of the semester. Other than that, it was a very enjoyable class.
class was too large for meaningful discussion, dissection of topics. a smaller class size would have been benefitial

FES needs to start building tracks where courses build upon each other. Otherwise, courses repeat so much. In this case, energy systems analysis should be a prerequisite for this course which is then taught at a much higher level of presumed energy knowledge.
I think the course should cover a little less topics in order to make a deeper analysis of some issues.

Rethinking the structure of the course might be a good idea. In the lectures, the professor tried to cover everything, which of course is impossible. As a result, I learned very, very little about very, very many aspects of energy in developing countries. A more in-depth focus on key areas would be helpful -- you can't cover everything that everyone wants to learn about energy in one class, but at least students would walk away with more concrete knowledge rather than broad exposure to a bunch of different ideas.Also, the discussion format did not help foster discussion. It would have been great to have the two TAs lead discussion section during the 2nd half of class, or to have the students lead discussion sections (instead of presenting to the entire class). There were people in the class who were real experts in a given week's topic, and discussion section would give us an opportunity to learn from each other.
My only suggestion is to be slightly more cognizant of the time devoted to lecture and discussion to allow for longer discussions.
The discussion session would be better if there were fewer people in the class.
The after class discussion was often difficult, mostly because of the large size of the class. Perhaps breaking the discussion section into smaller groups would foster more dialogue.
Discussion sessions get dull sometimes.

First, discussion section did not work. I have some theories about why: Bowers is not conducive to discussion. It's too big, echo-y, and we don't face each other. But beyond that (because that is easily fixed), there were too many people. I find that discussion with 25 is about the limit, and we had over 30. It should either be restricted, split intotwo groups, or discussion should be scrapped.Second, the structure of the course and the topic of lectures was not that great. I think the course spent far to long on development at the household level. I think one, maybe two lectures would be good, but not a third of the course. It started getting interesting at the national and especially international levels.Third, lecture always went over time, giving us only half an hour for discussion usually. I think there is virtue in only lecturing on the most important, the take-away message, instead of getting bogged down in the details. Time and content needs to be managed better.
The level at which it is taught
The weekly student facilitations - corny
Maybe add a few minutes to allow students to comment on/relay their own reading responses for each class?
Discussion sessions should be shorter, and dedicate more time for class time.

three hours can be too much. I dont like the discussion among students. I would prefere something led by the professor (lecture) or the TA. Student discussion in such a large class can get way to distracted and boring. Discussions get over concentrated among few students.It has such like a dispute for few second to "run the show". There is no time for everyone to talk.
The discussion sessions can be more stimulating. Also Bowers is too large for this class.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Grading comments on a scale of 3 can be retaught. Need a clearer policy on turning commentaries in late.
Prof. Bailis has very limited time availability. Need to extend office hours.
The instructor was always approachable and helpful, as were the TAs.
Help was mostly provided by the instructor during his office hours, and he had a great disposition.
Instructor gave great feedback for the final paper.
Fantastic availability and quality of help from both the instructor and TA.
TA, Yitian, helped me about the modeling project a lot.Professor Bailis gave me one-on-one instruction about the final paper.Both are very helpful.
Both the instructor and the TA were always available to help
The TAs were prompt and available to help.
They were very helpful
fine
Prof. Bailis was great - great with questions, well-informed lecturer, very smart guy. TAs were quiet but did provide 2-3 sentence reactions to our reading responses.
It was OK..could had use a bit more of help on the HOMER assignment
She replied and turned in all assignments on time. I would appreciate more time to discuss the homework.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Helpful for F&ES energy students to gain international, developing country perspective on our energy challenges.
This is a good course for anyone who doesn't have a strong background in energy to learn from.

As someone interested in sustainable development, this was a key element of my program. Energy is a critical part of development. Most significantly, this course goes beyond the technical aspects of development to discuss the implications on a social level.
I am aiming to secure a research position in energy and climate change policy and have previously had experience in carbon finance and renewable energy technologies in developing countries.
It percectly fit to my interest: development and energy policy
almost exactly my field of interest

I'm focused on energy but had, until this class, been thinking primarily about energy use in the U.S. This course opened me up to the significance of/challenges associated with energy use/access abroad and has actually changed my thinking about what I'll do after school. Thinking now about getting involved in energy development abroad, possibly via a development bank or NGO developingsmaller-scale renewables projects in developing countries. Understanding the social/human element in energy considerations abroad was a huge motivator.
it is essential to understand the human side of energy, Rob knows how to show you that.
Sure, if you are interested in energy, you should take it.
We need more classes in the energy curriculum, for everyone interested in energy this is a must do.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interested in energy policy and the economics of energy infrastructure.
Helpful to gain international, developing country perspective on our energy challenges.
See answer to Question 15.
interested in energy issues for developing countries
wanted to learn how to deal with a range of energy issues.
To learn more about energy, since there are not too many energy-focused courses at FES.
Having developed an interest in energy and hoping to work internationally, I wanted to deepen my knowledge of energy issues as they pertain to developing countries.
I am interested in energy in general
To learn energy issues in broader sense

My focus is in social ecology, especially in developing country contexts and I had never taken an energy course and really wanted to. So I thought this would fit perfectly. It didn't really, but for other reasons (see question 13)
I am interested in the topic.
to follow my main research interest

To broaden my understanding of energy issues. Again, I'd been focused primarily on U.S. energy issues. It's a totally different issue elsewhere - energy access, pollution, social impacts/displacement etc.
I am interested in Energy.
INterested in Energy and Developing countries, perfect fit.
I am interested in energy, and prof. Bailis is working in Brazil (my home country).

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.
Mixed bag. Lectures and readings were so so. The Homer assignment and paper were very valuable.
Yes, it provided a very good overview of the issues presented, and I learned a lot from the lectures and especially the assignments.
some what
Sort of - it covered a variety of issues but I'm not sure if it was practically useful.
Yes, the class provided an interesting amount of issues related to energy. However, I would have liked to explore some topics more deeply.
No
Yes
Yes.
Yes
Yes
Not really. The class was poorly organized and distracted from the content
No. It has great potential, but it was not well executed.
yes in that it reinforced the knowledge I already had.no in that it didn;t push that knowledge much further.
Yes.
yes it did, kind of slow but lots of valuable knowledge and new questions
Yes
yes. I learned a lot about energy, renewables, and biofuels.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
Mixed bag. Lectures and readings were so so. The Homer assignment and paper were very valuable.
Yes.
yes
Average. I got a general approach and knowledge about issues relating energy and the environment, but I would have liked to discuss some of them in greater detail.
No
Yes
Yes.
Yes
Yes
Yes
No, see question 13.
No. It was mostly a review of courses I've already taken.
expected to be pushed harder. expected more involved classroom debate.

More so. The inclusion of the anthropological elements of energy access etc at the beginning of the semester, while dry for me, were a welcome addition to the otherwise technical/policy-related work I've been doing on energy in other classes.
yes
Yes.
Yes. Gave me a broad pictures of energy development. From this class I can access many new resources to develop my carrer.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The HOMER assignment did involve a lot of work but, was fun.The discussion sections were not very useful. Smaller discussion sections where people are forced to talk, debate, disagree - more constructive.
Advantage - accomplished a large amount without the burden being on any one student.Disadvantage - trouble coordinating group time.
The Homer assignment is extensive and it helps to have several people to work on it.
Group work in doing the software assignment was very enjoyable and appropriate, we all learned a lot more working together.
The group work was a great experience. Each member brought a different vantage point and background to the project.

For this course I had the opportunity to work with students I don't normally do group projects with so it was an insightful experience to see how other people approach problems in a group setting. Group assignments also allowed us to learn from other members in the group who have knowledge indifferent areas.
Good to learn in depth

Advantages: they helped out with the modeling because I found it quite difficult. I think I would have really struggled on my own.Disadvantages: as with any group work, you have to coordinate, compromise, and communicate far more than with individual work.
advatnages: good to see how others learn, teamwork, different points of viewdisadvantages: different levels of familiaritywith the subject meant we couldn't really push the assigment very far
Was great to learn from each other on the HOMER project and in the discussion prep. Each of us could dive deeper into a paper or part of the HOMER problem as a result.
Great experience

I like to work in group to do our homework, including the project. But I did not like working in groups for our student discussion. Not productive. Students are no committed with the thing, and lack of knowledge to led the discussion. I would prefer to have a normal lecture lead by the professor.
Scheduling meetings is the toughest part.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Some things you'll like, others you won't care for too much. Mixed reviews. But do take the class if your knowledge of energy is limited to the US or developed countries and want to gain a broader perspective.
See answer to Question 15.
pick a term paper and specific topic you are interested in early on in the term
I wouldn't recommend the class if the structure remains the same.

If you're interested in the socioeconomic / development aspects of energy, this is the course for you. If you want a more technical treatment or one that focuses on developing countries, then you should look more carefully at the syllabus and talk to the instructor to make sure that you can find value in it.
To be concerned about the workload from the weekly commentary
This is a good class to take if you're interested in getting to learn more about energy policy holistically. I would recommend doing the readings and being able to participate in class.
go go go if you are interested in the intersection between technology and social issues around energy

Do all the readings - each will inform discussions the next day and your understanding of the many issues associated with energy development. Don't wait 'til the last minute to do HOMER. The more time you put in, the more you'll get out of it.
its hard at first to go through the lectures, but at the end its worthed
You should take it. Readings are ussually interesting. Prof. Bailis is great but not excellent at times.
If you are interested in energy do it. Try to convince the professor for not doing student lead in class discusion. He can do a better job than you do. He could lead the discussion over the readings.
Spend more time on Homer.
